intro: Helopus tridentatus, commonly known as the three-toothed helopus, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Araliaceae and is characterized by its distinctive trifoliate leaves, each leaflet having a serrated edge. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in umbels, typical of its family. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in tropical and subtropical forests. Due to its unique morphology and limited distribution, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
